children.subject: I somewhat disagree - you definitely don't need 'extensive' systems and C knowledge. The main things you need to understand are stack layout and some basic C/assembly which is around the first 3 weeks of the course. If you're willing to self-study that portion of the class beforehand you should be fine (I took 161 w/o 61C + have TA'd and had students do the same thing and do well)
I advise you to take 161 after 61C, unless you have extensive systems knowledge and programming experience in C.
Also Weaver places more weight on exams, so 61C is definitely a lot harder than Hilfinger's 61B. Recommend taking 61C and 189 together since both professors have fair exams.

Thank you so much Xinyun! That's very good advice :).

May I ask about is there any 3rd light tech course recommended? Thank you!

STAT 134 is a good choice if you consider double major in statistics. It's a fair course and doesn't have any programming components. STAT 135 has some basic r programming and a little bit overlap with 189 in MLE. I think some courses like STAT 134, 135 or MATH 110 (I haven't taken that) which don't have programming are ok. Or if you like economics, consider ECON 100A/100B (they count as tech electives).

I'm not sure why you're making the correlation between programming and work.. that's definitely something which depends on the person. I know many people who would find those classes much more time consuming than something like 186.

To OP I'd recommend going through Piazza - questions on low workload techs have been asked many times.
I forgot 186. 186 is ok to add, except the last project took me quite a long time.

I did CS 61C with Weaver and 189 with Shewchuk last spring with STAT 153, got A+ in 61C and A in 189, used late drop for 153 at the end of that semester. First half of semester was ok because you have slip days, but I used all the slip days in the first half and the second half of semester was horrible... Weaver's 61C is a lot of work, trust me... The projects are hard and office hours are like 1 TA with 100 students waiting. The first projects in C were really hard and you are unable to finish them without going to OH. The last project was in Go, which was nearly impossible to debug by yourself. Imagine a semester with all Hilfinger styles' projects and due once every two weeks. Shewchuk's 189 was less work than 61C actually, but the coding homework in neural network took a lot of time, since training neural network takes hours and you need to try many parameters to train it to achieve the accuracy. I dropped 153 because I had no slip days left that day the neural network homework was due and I bombed the exam without reviewing, and I think 161 is more work than 153. Personally I think taking 61C + 189 is already a lot of work, adding 161 is too much.

history.content:
Hi all! 

I know it is very early but I am planing my long-term schedule right now. I wish to take 189 as early as possible in order to seek out researches, and I have adequate linear algebra background. I understand that 61C with weaver is even heavier than 61B with hilfinger, but if I take 61C with Weaver + 189 with Shewchuk + 161 on a semester, will that be doable (aim for As)? Does anyone have similar experiences?

Thank you so much!
history.subject: sp20: 61C with Weaver + 189 with Shewchuk + 161 doable?
